abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Sixth Highway Rehabilitation Project in
            Tanzania. The objectives of the project, were to: (i) reduce
            the transport costs by rehabilitating the most important
            sections of the highway network;( ii) improve the system of
            road maintenance works by increasing contractors rather than
            by force account; (iii) assist and expand the capacity and
            efficiency of the trucking industry; and (iv) increase the
            availability of trained engineers in Tanzania.  Bank's
            performance was satisfactory. Borrower's performance
            was satisfactory. The key lessons learned were as follows:
            (i) main institutional and policy changes,including
            reorganization and institutional reinforcement of roads
            administration as well as changes in the procurement
            regulations should be undertaken prior to project
            effectiveness; (ii) it would be appropriate to annually
            review the program and to phase it with implementation
            progress,using subsequent fund releases based on continuing
            institutional reforms and strengthening; (iii) A carefulr
            eevaluation  of the engineering design prior to actual
            commencement of works would avoid such delays and cost
            overruns; (iv) road networks are deteriorating faster than
            the level of investments to rehabilitate and to maintain
            them; (v) establish a maintenance strategy for the roads;
            (vi) improve the regulatory environment to stimulate the
            development of the private sector; and (vii) public sector
            based equipment rehabilitation programs do not work.
